content.statement: aaa-013-mycotic-aneurysm is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Aaa that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding aaa-013-mycotic-aneurysm helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of aaa-013-mycotic-aneurysm include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of aaa-013-mycotic-aneurysm.

common_organisms.salmonella: Most common in elderly, especially Salmonella enteritidis, typhimurium
common_organisms.staphylococcus_aureus: Common with IV drug use, endocarditis

definitions_glossary.mycotic_aneurysm: Infected arterial aneurysm caused by bacterial seeding (despite the fungal-sounding name)
definitions_glossary.saccular_aneurysm: Asymmetric, focal outpouching affecting only part of the arterial circumference
definitions_glossary.septic_embolus: Infected clot that travels through bloodstream and lodges in arterial wall

antibiotics.duration: Minimum 6 weeks IV, often lifelong oral suppression

open_repair.in_situ_reconstruction: With rifampin-soaked Dacron or cryopreserved allograft
open_repair.extra_anatomic_bypass: Axillobifemoral with aortic ligation if severe contamination

endovascular.role: Bridge therapy in hemodynamically unstable patients
endovascular.concerns: Placing graft in infected field, requires prolonged antibiotics
endovascular.outcomes: Acceptable short-term, higher late infection rate

prognosis.late_infection: Risk of graft infection, especially with in situ prosthetic repair

definition.@value: Infected arterial aneurysm caused by bacterial seeding of the arterial wall

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical and imaging features of mycotic aneurysm
Plan surgical approach for infected aneurysm
clinical_pearls: Salmonella + elderly patient + GI symptoms = high suspicion for mycotic aneurysm
Blood cultures are positive in only 50-75% - negative cultures do not exclude diagnosis
Saccular, rapidly enlarging, atypical location = think infected
Cryopreserved allograft may have lower reinfection rate than prosthetic
